awd_titl_txt: Integrated Support and Community Engagement to Increase Undergraduate Recruitment, Retention, and Graduation in Physical Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, this project will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at Weber State University. Over the five years of funding, this project will provide scholarships to 30 students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in the physical sciences including chemistry, geoscience, mathematics, physics, computer science, and engineering. The program will also support the Scholars through graduation with a system of academic support services that emphasizes the development of community leadership and involvement. Scholars will complete their coursework in cohorts, attend a weekly STEM seminar course, meet regularly with faculty mentors, and participate in leadership opportunities. The goal of the project is to improve the four-year graduation rate of the Scholars from 12% to 50%.  Moreover, the project will investigate and assess which interventions are the most significant to improve student success and persistence to degree completion for this population of students. 

This project aims to lower the unmet financial need of low-income, high-achieving students, and implement evidence-based interventions to enhance student success. The interventions include targeted recruitment to STEM degrees, student academic cohorts, STEM faculty mentors, and a STEM seminar course responsive to students as they progress through the program. An important aspect of the program is a consistent focus on engaging the Scholars in their community, including participation in community engaged learning projects.  By using student focus groups, the project will investigate students' perceptions of STEM careers and assess the effectiveness of these interventions within the context of regional student demographics. The research results will provide formative assessment to guide ongoing project improvements and will identify effective strategies for recruiting and retaining future students.  These results can also provide information to other institutions that aim to increase the participation and success of STEM students from diverse, low-income populations in which cultural or religious beliefs may discourage pursuit of a STEM degree.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: In 2019, Weber State University received a $648,798 NSF S-STEM award.The goal of the project was to increase the retention and graduation of low-income, academically talented students who are STEM majors by following various best practices listed below.

Provide scholarships: The goal was to provide scholarships to at least 30 students. Students who received scholarships and who were provided the various supports were called WEST Scholars. A total of 66 WEST Scholars received at least one semester scholarship of $2,500, 38% of them women. However, the majority of scholars received between a one year to 3 years of scholarships through the WEST program. Five scholars received between 4 to 5 years of scholarships. Of the $450,000 meant for scholarships, $433,018.25 was dispersed. Several challenges occurred during the grant period that impacted the number of scholars served. The first was that the COVID-19 pandemic occurred during the first and second years of the program closing the university temporarily, moving all courses online, and hampering recruiting efforts at high schools. In addition, it took several years to develop the best mechanism for identifying and recruiting low-income students. Originally, students needed to apply to be a part of the WEST program by writing an essay, obtaining letters of recommendation, and submitting a video. However, the leadership team determined after conducting focus groups with students that the application process was too cumbersome. In addition, the marketing of the scholarship through teachers, social media, and the website was not recruiting enough students. The more crucial challenge was that even when students were aware of the program and applied, not all students had financial need as determined by FAFSA criteria. Therefore, in the last two years of the grant, students were identified for the program by first having college advisors identify STEM majors and then having financial aid officers identify which of those students had financial need.  

Graduation and Retention: As of Fall 2024, of the 66 scholars who received at least one semester of scholarship money, 36% (n=24) have graduated. Of the remaining 42 scholars, 64% (n=27) have been retained as they are registered for Fall 2024 courses. The remaining 23% (n=15) of scholars have left the program or university or are not registered for the Fall 2024 semester. It is important to note that given that this was a 5-year grant, depending on how many credit hours scholars had when they first started the WEST program, only scholars in the first 3 cohorts had the possibility of graduating within a 5-year period. Scholars receiving a scholarship within the last two years of the grant, are unlikely to have been able to graduate unless they were already seniors. These factors impact the calculation of graduation and retention rates.

Creation of cohorts: The challenge of the creation of cohorts became apparent within the first two years of the grant. The challenge mainly derived from the fact that WEST scholars had varied majors across two different colleges, different courses needed, and different schedules.

STEM Seminar and creating STEM Leadership Opportunities and community involvement opportunities: The STEM seminar was offered for 4 of the 5 years of the grant and for 2 of the years it was offered online rather than face to face. In addition, due to the small number of WEST Scholars, they were enrolled in a combined STEM seminar. The purpose of the seminar was to build a community among students and faculty in a welcoming environment and a way to create social connections among the students. In the last year of the grant, it was not offered because eligible scholars were identified only a couple of weeks before the Fall semester making it too late to create the course. WEST Scholars were informed and encouraged to be involved in various educational opportunities through the STEM seminar and through faculty advising.

Faculty Mentors and Advising: For the two of five years of the grant, faculty member mentors were assigned to each Scholar. Mentors would advise on curriculum and programs, support in navigating university and college services, and inform scholars of high impact educational opportunities available in their major to provide additional one-on-one advising and connection with faculty members in their major.

Fostering STEM identity that is compatible with their gender, ethnic, and religious identities: The cohorts, STEM seminar, and advising were meant to help develop a strong STEM identity.  In general, WEST Scholars reported having a sense of belonging in their major and STEM identity. They appreciated the financial aid they’ve received, the academic community they have developed, and the mentorship, overall support, and research opportunities they have received.

Summary: The WEST Scholars program provided financial, advising, and mentoring support facilitating retention and graduation of STEM students.


Last Modified: 12/16/2024
Modified by: Tracy Covey
